unnormalised: The summer after my Class 10 board exams was supposed to be relaxing, a break before the storm of Class 11. But that's when my parents decided I needed "coaching." Specifically, for the IIT-JEE. I had no idea what JEE even meant, but the brochures plastered everywhere screamed “Success!” and “Future Engineers!” at every corner, especially around Kota, Rajasthan.
normalised: The summer after my Class ten board exams was supposed to be relaxing, a break before the storm of Class eleven. But that's when my parents decided I needed "coaching." Specifically, for the I-I-T J-E-E. I had no idea what J-E-E even meant, but the brochures plastered everywhere screamed “Success!” and “Future Engineers!” at every corner, especially around Kota, Rajasthan.

unnormalised: We visited a couple of coaching centers. "VMC" (Vidyalankar Madhyamik Classes) was all the rage, promising personalized attention. Then there was "FIITJEE," a national brand, seemingly the Microsoft of JEE coaching. My parents finally settled on "Resonance," a massive, multi-story building churning out engineers by the thousands. The fees? A cool Rs. 1.5 lakh for 2 years. Seemed like a small fortune.
normalised: We visited a couple of coaching centers. "V-M-C" (Vidyalankar Madhyamik Classes) was all the rage, promising personalized attention. Then there was "F-I-I-T-J-E-E," a national brand, seemingly the Microsoft of J-E-E coaching. My parents finally settled on "Resonance," a massive, multi-story building churning out engineers by the thousands. The fees? A cool rupee one point five lakh for two years. Seemed like a small fortune.

unnormalised: My classes started on 01/06/2016. The schedule was brutal: 8 AM to 6 PM, 6 days a week. Physics, Chemistry, and Maths. Each subject had its own "sir," who taught like our lives depended on understanding every concept, every formula. The pressure was immense. Mock tests every Sunday, results ranked nationally. I remember scoring a miserable 45% in one of those tests.
normalised: My classes started on first june two thousand and sixteen. The schedule was brutal: eight A-M to six P-M, six days a week. Physics, Chemistry, and Maths. Each subject had its own "sir," who taught like our lives depended on understanding every concept, every formula. The pressure was immense. Mock tests every Sunday, results ranked nationally. I remember scoring a miserable forty five percent in one of those tests.

unnormalised: The town of Kota was a pressure cooker. Every other student was preparing for JEE or NEET. The competition was palpable. "AIR," All India Rank, became the only metric that mattered. Friends became rivals. Chai breaks were spent discussing formulas and strategies. I even remember a guy, probably around 17 yrs old, break down crying outside Allen Career Institute when he got a bad score.
normalised: The town of Kota was a pressure cooker. Every other student was preparing for J-E-E or N-E-E-T. The competition was palpable. "A-I-R," All India Rank, became the only metric that mattered. Friends became rivals. Chai breaks were spent discussing formulas and strategies. I even remember a guy, probably around seventeen years old, break down crying outside Allen Career Institute when he got a bad score.

unnormalised: Despite the relentless pressure, there were moments of camaraderie. Late-night study sessions with friends, quick trips to the nearby "lassi wala" for a sugar fix. There were also plenty of pep talks from teachers and mentors, trying to convince us that we were "all winners" and that success was just around the corner if we put in 10 hours of study everyday.

unnormalised: Ultimately, I didn't crack the IIT-JEE. I got a decent rank, enough to get into a good NIT (National Institute of Technology), but not IIT. Looking back, the coaching experience was a mixed bag. I learned a lot, sure, but I also lost a bit of myself in the process. Was it worth Rs 1.5 lakh? Probably not. But it definitely prepared me for the cutthroat world of engineering, even if it wasn’t at IIT.
